names.description: The name Ad Dhaar is a reminder that while Allah is generous and gives us countless blessings, He also is the one who determines when harm will befall a person, whether as a punishment or as a test. However, when faced with calamity, we must remember that Allah doesn't give us hardship in vain, and we are able to purify ourselves and receive rewards through these trials. We should seek forgiveness and be patient when encountering difficulty, and remain steadfast. We are also reminded that Allah is merciful, but He will also return to us the consequences of our actions.

names.name: An Naafi'
names.appearances: Does not directly appear in the Quran, but is described
names.arabicText: وَلَا تَدۡعُ مِن دُونِ ٱللَّهِ مَا لَا يَنفَعُكَ وَلَا يَضُرُّكَۖ فَإِن فَعَلۡتَ فَإِنَّكَ إِذٗا مِّنَ ٱلظَّـٰلِمِينَ
names.translation: And do not invoke besides Allah that which neither benefits you nor harms you, for if you did, then indeed you would be of the wrongdoers.'
names.description: The name An Naafi' is the counterpart to Ad Dhaar, and implies that although Allah is the one who punishes the disobedient, He is also the one who grants us so many blessings. By taking these two names together, it shows the complementary nature of Allah. We shouldn't attribute any evil or bad conditions to Allah, since He acts justly and according to His greater wisdom. When we view any negative circumstances, we should always also consider the good things that we still have and remain grateful.

names.name: An Noor
names.appearances: The word "noor" appears more than 40 times in the Quran
names.arabicText: يَـٰٓأَهۡلَ ٱلۡكِتَٰبِ قَدۡ جَآءَكُمۡ رَسُولُنَا يُبَيِّنُ لَكُمۡ كَثِيرٗا مِّمَّا كُنتُمۡ تُخۡفُونَ مِنَ ٱلۡكِتَٰبِ وَيَعۡفُواْ عَن كَثِيرٖۚ قَدۡ جَآءَكُم مِّنَ ٱللَّهِ نُورٞ وَكِتَٰبٞ مُّبِينٞ
names.translation: O People of the Scripture, there has come to you Our Messenger making clear to you much of what you used to conceal of the Scripture and overlooking much. There has come to you from Allah a light and a clear Book.
names.description: The name An Noor describes Allah's countenance as such that His magnificence is too bright and great for us to be able to bear seeing. Another interpretation is that He is the one that provides the light of knowledge, and His light reveals all that we try to hide. He illuminates the path to His guidance, and without His help, we would be confused and misguided. We are also reminded here that no one can hide anything from Allah, as He is As Samee' (The All-Hearing) and Al Baseer (The All-Seeing). Each of us has our own light that benefits and guides others around us, drawing them closer to Allah. On the Day of Judgement, it is this light that will illuminate our path on the Siraat to Jannah, so we should always ask Allah to brighten our light of goodness.
names.additionalInfo: Dua to ask Allah for light: Sahih Bukhari 6316

names.name: Al Haadi
names.appearances: Does not directly appear in the Quran, but is described
names.arabicText: إِنَّكَ لَا تَهۡدِي مَنۡ أَحۡبَبۡتَ وَلَٰكِنَّ ٱللَّهَ يَهۡدِي مَن يَشَآءُۚ وَهُوَ أَعۡلَمُ بِٱلۡمُهۡتَدِينَ
names.translation: Indeed, [O Muhammad], you do not guide whom you like, but Allah guides whom He wills. And He is most knowing of the [rightly] guided.
names.description: The name Al Haadi is related to An Noor, since the light helps to guide the way. Allah has sent various means to guide us, such as the Quran, the prophets and messengers, and the hadiths of His last messenger: the Prophet Muhammad (SAW). We must study both the hadiths and the Quran in order to receive full guidance, and must not neglect either one in favor of the other since both were sent by Allah for the purpose of instructing us. Allah is the only source of guidance, but Prophet Muhammad (SAW) served a role similar to a doctor, in that he advised us based on Allah's commands that we need to follow. However, it is up to us whether we implement these into our lives and benefit from this guidance or not.

names.name: Al Badee'
names.arabicText: بَدِيعُ ٱلسَّمَٰوَٰتِ وَٱلۡأَرۡضِۖ أَنَّىٰ يَكُونُ لَهُۥ وَلَدٞ وَلَمۡ تَكُن لَّهُۥ صَٰحِبَةٞۖ وَخَلَقَ كُلَّ شَيۡءٖۖ وَهُوَ بِكُلِّ شَيۡءٍ عَلِيمٞ
names.translation: [He is] Originator of the heavens and the earth. How could He have a son when He does not have a companion and He created all things? And He is, of all things, Knowing.
names.description: The name Al Badee', relating back to Al Awwal (The First), describes Allah as being the both the original being and the originator of everything in existence. This can also be considered a name of creation, alongside Al Khaliq (The Creator), Al Bari' (The Maker), and Al Musawwir (The Fashioner). Nothing predates Him and no one has the capability or power to do what He can. Allah is completely unique and dissimilar to anything else, and He has also created each of us to be unique from other humans. From our fingerprints to our personalities and experiences, each one of us is different and special. Rather than feeling negative about standing out, we should strive to improve ourselves and distinguish ourselves in the sight of Allah.

names.name: Al Baaqi
names.appearances: Does not directly appear in the Quran
names.arabicText: مَا عِندَكُمۡ يَنفَدُ وَمَا عِندَ ٱللَّهِ بَاقٖۗ وَلَنَجۡزِيَنَّ ٱلَّذِينَ صَبَرُوٓاْ أَجۡرَهُم بِأَحۡسَنِ مَا كَانُواْ يَعۡمَلُونَ
names.translation: Whatever you have will end, but what Allah has is lasting. And We will surely give those who were patient their reward according to the best of what they used to do.
names.description: The name Al Baaqi shows that Allah has always been and will always be present. Unlike Al Awwal (The First) and Al Aakhir (The Last), this name shows that Allah transcends time and is not limited by it in any way. His existence is necessary for all other things to exist, or in other words, we are all dependent on Him. In contrast, our lives are finite and the time we have is quickly waning. As a result, this should serve as a reminder that we must take advantage of the time we have left for our benefit in the Hereafter.

names.name: Al Waarith
names.arabicText: وَكَمْ أَهْلَكْنَا مِن قَرْيَةٍۭ بَطِرَتْ مَعِيشَتَهَا ۖ فَتِلْكَ مَسَـٰكِنُهُمْ لَمْ تُسْكَن مِّنۢ بَعْدِهِمْ إِلَّا قَلِيلًۭا ۖ وَكُنَّا نَحْنُ ٱلْوَٰرِثِينَ
names.translation: And how many a city have We destroyed that was insolent in its [way of] living, and those are their dwellings which have not been inhabited after them except briefly. And it is We who were the inheritors.
names.description: The name Al Waarith shows that since everything that we have belongs to Allah, after our lives end, all of it will return back to Him; the true owner. It also highlights that Allah is everlasting (Al Baaqi) and will always exist after all of us pass away. Allah has no partners, and thus He is the sole inheritor and owner of everything. None of the worldly possessions that we hoard and covet in this life will stay with us forever, so we should instead place our importance on our deeds which are the only thing that will stay with us after death.

names.name: Ar Rasheed
names.appearances: Does not directly appear in the Quran, but is described
names.arabicText: إِذۡ أَوَى ٱلۡفِتۡيَةُ إِلَى ٱلۡكَهۡفِ فَقَالُواْ رَبَّنَآ ءَاتِنَا مِن لَّدُنكَ رَحۡمَةٗ وَهَيِّئۡ لَنَا مِنۡ أَمۡرِنَا رَشَدٗا
names.translation: [Mention] when the youths retreated to the cave and said, 'Our Lord, grant us from Yourself mercy and prepare for us from our affair right guidance.'
names.description: The name Ar Rasheed implies that Allah is the one who provides the correct guidance. While this is similar to Al Haadi (The Guide), Ar Rasheed emphasizes this by eliminating the possibility of misguidance. He made Islam easy for us to understand so that we can learn and follow the path to guidance. When facing a problem, we should always ask Allah to guide our judgment so that we make the right choice on how to proceed, since He is the source of right guidance and has unparalleled wisdom.

names.name: As Saboor
names.appearances: Does not directly appear in the Quran
names.arabicText: يَـٰٓأَيُّهَا ٱلَّذِينَ ءَامَنُواْ ٱسۡتَعِينُواْ بِٱلصَّبۡرِ وَٱلصَّلَوٰةِۚ إِنَّ ٱللَّهَ مَعَ ٱلصَّـٰبِرِينَ
names.translation: O you who have believed, seek help through patience and prayer. Indeed, Allah is with the patient.
names.description: The name As Saboor describes the immense patience that Allah treats us with. No matter how many mistakes we make, He doesn't immediately destroy or punish us, but instead continues to give us chances to ask forgiveness and turn back to Him. Allah is patient Himself, and loves those who are patient. Therefore, we should practice this quality by abstaining from our desires that may seem enticing but will harm us in reality. We should also strive to retain patience when someone or something upsets us, or when a situation is unfavorable to us. Instead of becoming angry, using foul language, or falling into sorrow, it is better to endure whatever comes our way with patience.
names.additionalInfo: "The believer who mixes with people and bears their annoyance with patience will have a greater reward than the believer who does not mix with people and does not put up with their annoyance." - Sahih (Darussalam) Sunan Ibn Majah 4032
